awd_titl_txt: Creating Three-Dimensional Fundamental Flame Database Using Novel Diagnostics
awd_abstract_narration:
Many open questions remain in the study of turbulent combustion, hindering the design of next-generation energy systems. A key gap in our knowledge is the lack of proper experimental data that can be used to validate and inspire predictive models. Due to the inherent three-dimensional (3D) spatial structures of practical turbulent flames, instantaneous 3D measurements of fundamental flame properties have been long desired for use in model development. However, existing experimental efforts are predominately limited to obtaining data at a point, along a line, or across a 2D plane. This project is to develop novel diagnostics that can enable 3D measurements in flames. These valuable experimental data will be used for model validation and development. The knowledge generated in this project will help with the design and optimization of propulsion and energy systems utilizing combustion. Additional efforts in this project include establishing collaborations across boundaries of disciplines and institutions as well as engaging industry to accelerate technology transfer.

Turbulent combustion is governed by the intricate interactions between chemical reactions and turbulence. Such interactions inherently occur in 3D, and consequently measurements that can resolve the variations of combustion properties in all three dimensions have long been desired. This project will address this long-standing need with a two-phase plan. In the first phase, the team will investigate and utilize three novel 3D diagnostic techniques, including high resolution tomography, machine learning assisted diagnostics, and hybrid 3D diagnostics. In the second phase, the team will apply these new diagnostics to obtain 3D measurements of fundamental combustion properties in canonical turbulent flames. The target properties include 3D flame topography and 3D-3-component velocity. Both are crucial for understanding turbulent flame dynamics and improving model accuracy. This research is highly interdisciplinary and can contribute to fundamental combustion science, optical diagnostics, and computational modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research project is to address a knowledge gap in the area of turbulent combustion: the need for multidimensional experimental data with quantifiable accuracy. The lack of such data is hindering the validation of predictive models. Against this background, the intellectual merit of this project lies in both the fundamental scientific significance of flame-flow interaction and also its ubiquitous application in a wide range of practical devices. Without a good fundamental understanding and reliable predictive models, practical applications tend to rely on expensive trials and iterations.

To address this issue, this project described a two-phase plan to provide fundamental flame data in three-dimensional (3D) using novel diagnostics. In the first phase, the PI proposed to investigate several novel 3D diagnostic techniques to enable 3D measurements on a large scale with better resolution and accuracy. In the second phase, the PI proposed to apply these new diagnostics to obtain 3D measurements of fundamental properties in canonical flames. Under this overall framework, the project started by developing techniques that can experimentally quantify 3D measurement accuracy. Based on quantifiable accuracy, the project then explored a range of new diagnostic techniques and found several of them to be particularly effective. The first notable example is the technique to perform 3D tomography reconstruction in combination with the conservation laws as regularizations. The second example is the development of a method to correct beam steering in situ. We have identified beam steering as a major source of uncertainty for quantitative 3D turbulent flame measurements. Our method used a guiding laser to monitor the steering in situ and then correct it via post-processing. These techniques have been demonstrated to improve measurement accuracy substantially. For example, by incorporating the conservation of mass as a priori information into the 3D reconstruction process, our results showed an enhancement of accuracy by 40% to 50% in terms of velocity magnitude and by 0.6 to 1.1 degrees in terms of velocity orientation compared to the existing 3D velocimetry technique.

The final roadblock this project addressed involves the computational issue of applying these new techniques to practical measurements. Even with their fundamental merits demonstrated in the first phase, applying the new techniques to practical measurements still faces tremendous computational challenges due to the dimensions of the problem. For instance, experimental data involved in this project routinely required reconstruction based on ~5 million inputs per frame of measurement. To make it feasible to systematically process experimental data obtained in practice, the project has developed a few techniques to reduce the overall computational time while maintaining the reconstruction accuracy. These techniques are based on various ideas (such as 3D masking and dynamic meshing), but the common theme is to concentrate computational resources on regions of high interest.

The broader impact of this work is multifaceted. The research efforts have combined optical tomography, combustion science, and big data analysis (necessitated by the 3D nature of the diagnostics proposed). This project bridges disciplines of energy, photonics, and information technology, all critical areas of contemporary societal importance. To maximize its broader impact, the PI has integrated large portions of the research into his teaching and outreach activities. During the span of this project, the PI has integrated materials from this project into several large undergraduate courses taught routinely at his home institution, including heat transfer, aerodynamics, and aero propulsion. The PI also pursued collaborations extensively, both within his home institution and beyond, in areas encompassing large-scale computing, combustion modeling, and monitoring of practical propulsion devices. These collaborations helped to maximize the broader impact of this project and also train students in a collaborative environment across disciplines. This project has helped the professional development of both the PI and several students. Notably, the project has sponsored the work of two PhD students, both completed their dissertations and started their own academic careers.
